feed.title: Combined summary - Add a moving checkpoint to the Bitcoin protocol

entry.title: Combined summary - Add a moving checkpoint to the Bitcoin protocol
entry.summary: A proposal has been made to add a "moving checkpoint" rule to the Bitcoin protocol, which would allow nodes to ignore any new block below a certain height, making the blockchain immutable for blocks older than that. The proposal is being discussed among developers, but concerns have been raised about its potential limitations and vulnerabilities, particularly in cases of state-sponsored network splits lasting longer than the set limit.To address these concerns, suggestions have been made to improve the security of the rule, including adding a limit of X blocks to decide if the moving checkpoint is ignored or not. The length of X blocks could be measured as numberOfBlocks * averageBlockDifficulty to take into account any difficulty adjustment that happens during the time interval. Lord James proposed the moving checkpoint to address network splits that last longer than the set limit by having nodes stop until the split is fixed, and in extreme cases, nodes from one branch could delete their local history to join the other branch.Two possible situations are considered: protecting older blocks against history rewrites during a 51% attack and addressing network splits. The moving checkpoint is only valid if the difference in blocks between the main chain and the new fork is smaller than X blocks, like for example 3 days of blocks. If a node sees a fork longer than its main chain, and the fork has at least X blocks more than the main chain, then the node ignores the moving checkpoint rule and follows the fork, the longest chain. However, concerns have been raised about the vulnerability of this rule to 51% attacks.The proposal and potential issues surrounding it are being discussed among members of the Bitcoin-dev community. In a discussion about a potential state-sponsored netsplit lasting longer than N blocks (24 hours), concerns were raised about the difficulty of detecting a netsplit and the error-prone and centralizing nature of manual out-of-band communications. In the extreme case where no one notices a network split for more than N blocks and there are 2 permanent forks longer than N, nodes from one branch could delete their local history to join the other branch. However, concerns have been raised about China hosting more than 51% of hashpower and conducting a netsplit, and whether the rest of the world would have to delete their local history because they lack the hashpower to assert themselves as the proper branch.Overall, while the moving checkpoint proposal aims to improve security, concerns have been raised regarding its potential vulnerabilities and implementation challenges. It has been suggested that the rule should be adopted only after thorough testing and analysis.
